texts.text: (3) Until provision is made by 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] under clause (2), the Speaker or, as the case may be, the Chairman may, with the approval of the President, make rules 2 regulating the recruitment, and the conditions of service, of persons appointed to the secretarial staff of the National Assembly or the Senate.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 88. (1) The  expenditure  of  the  National  Assembly  and  the  Senate within  authorised  appropriations  shall  be  controlled  by  the  National Assembly or, as the case may be, the Senate acting on the advice of its Finance Committee.
texts.text: 88. (1) The  expenditure  of  the  National  Assembly  and  the  Senate within  authorised  appropriations  shall  be  controlled  by  the  National Assembly or, as the case may be, the Senate acting on the advice of its Finance Committee.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) The Finance Committee shall consist of the Speaker or, as the  case  may  be,  the  Chairman,  the  Minister  of  Finance  and  such  other members as may be elected thereto by the National Assembly or, as the case may be, the Senate.
texts.text: (2) The Finance Committee shall consist of the Speaker or, as the  case  may  be,  the  Chairman,  the  Minister  of  Finance  and  such  other members as may be elected thereto by the National Assembly or, as the case may be, the Senate.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) The Finance Committee may make rules 1  for regulating its procedure.
texts.text: (3) The Finance Committee may make rules 1  for regulating its procedure.

texts.orig: 3 [ 91. (1) There  shall  be  a  Cabinet  of  Ministers,  with  the  Prime Minister at its head, to aid and advise the President in the exercise of his functions.
texts.text: 3 [ 91. (1) There  shall  be  a  Cabinet  of  Ministers,  with  the  Prime Minister at its head, to aid and advise the President in the exercise of his functions.

texts.orig: (2) The National Assembly shall meet on the twenty-first day following  the  day  on  which  a  general  election  to  the  Assembly  is  held, unless sooner summoned by the President.
texts.text: (2) The National Assembly shall meet on the twenty-first day following  the  day  on  which  a  general  election  to  the  Assembly  is  held, unless sooner summoned by the President.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) After the election of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, the  National  Assembly  shall,  to  the  exclusion  of  any  other  business, proceed  to  elect  without  debate  one  of  its  Muslim  members  to  be  the Prime Minister.
texts.text: (3) After the election of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, the  National  Assembly  shall,  to  the  exclusion  of  any  other  business, proceed  to  elect  without  debate  one  of  its  Muslim  members  to  be  the Prime Minister.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (4) The  Prime  Minister  shall  be  elected  by  the  votes  of  the majority of the total membership of the National Assembly:
texts.text: (4) The  Prime  Minister  shall  be  elected  by  the  votes  of  the majority of the total membership of the National Assembly:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided that, if no member secures such majority in the first poll, a  second  poll  shall  be  held  between  the  members  who  secure  the  two highest numbers of votes in the first poll and the member who secures a majority of votes of the members present and voting shall be declared to have been elected as Prime Minister:
texts.text: Provided that, if no member secures such majority in the first poll, a  second  poll  shall  be  held  between  the  members  who  secure  the  two highest numbers of votes in the first poll and the member who secures a majority of votes of the members present and voting shall be declared to have been elected as Prime Minister:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided  further  that,  if  the  number  of  votes  secured  by  two  or more members securing the highest number of votes is equal, further poll shall be held between them until one of them secures a majority of votes
texts.text: Provided  further  that,  if  the  number  of  votes  secured  by  two  or more members securing the highest number of votes is equal, further poll shall be held between them until one of them secures a majority of votes

texts.text: (5) The member elected under clause (4) shall be called upon by  the  President  to  assume  the  office  of  Prime  Minister  and  he  shall, before entering upon the office, make before the President oath in the form set out in the Third Schedule:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided that there shall be no restriction on the number of terms for the office of the Prime Minister.
texts.text: Provided that there shall be no restriction on the number of terms for the office of the Prime Minister.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (6) The Cabinet, together with the Ministers of State, shall be collectively responsible to the Senate and the National Assembly.
texts.text: (6) The Cabinet, together with the Ministers of State, shall be collectively responsible to the Senate and the National Assembly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (7) The Prime Minister shall hold office during the pleasure of the  President,  but  the  President  shall  not  exercise  his  powers  under  this clause unless he is satisfied that the Prime Minister does not command the confidence of the majority of the members of the National Assembly, in which case he shall summon the National Assembly and require the Prime Minister to obtain a vote of confidence from the Assembly.
texts.text: (7) The Prime Minister shall hold office during the pleasure of the  President,  but  the  President  shall  not  exercise  his  powers  under  this clause unless he is satisfied that the Prime Minister does not command the confidence of the majority of the members of the National Assembly, in which case he shall summon the National Assembly and require the Prime Minister to obtain a vote of confidence from the Assembly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (8) The  Prime  Minister may,  by  writing under his  hand addressed to the President, resign his office.
texts.text: (8) The  Prime  Minister may,  by  writing under his  hand addressed to the President, resign his office.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (9) A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not  a  member  of  the  National  Assembly  shall,  at  the  expiration  of  that period, cease to be a Minister and shall not before the dissolution of that Assembly be again appointed a Minister unless he is elected a member of that Assembly :
texts.text: (9) A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not  a  member  of  the  National  Assembly  shall,  at  the  expiration  of  that period, cease to be a Minister and shall not before the dissolution of that Assembly be again appointed a Minister unless he is elected a member of that Assembly :

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided  that  nothing  contained  in  this  clause  shall  apply  to  a Minister who is member of the Senate.
texts.text: Provided  that  nothing  contained  in  this  clause  shall  apply  to  a Minister who is member of the Senate.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (10) Nothing  contained  in  this  Article  shall  be  construed  as disqualifying  the  Prime  Minister  or  any  other  Minister  or  a  Minister  of State for continuing in office during any period during which the National Assembly  stands  dissolved,  or  as  preventing  the  appointment  of  any person as Prime Minister or other Minister or a Minister of State during any such period.]
texts.text: (10) Nothing  contained  in  this  Article  shall  be  construed  as disqualifying  the  Prime  Minister  or  any  other  Minister  or  a  Minister  of State for continuing in office during any period during which the National Assembly  stands  dissolved,  or  as  preventing  the  appointment  of  any person as Prime Minister or other Minister or a Minister of State during any such period.]

texts.text: 95. (1)    A resolution for a vote of no-confidence moved by not less than twenty per centum of the total membership of the National Assembly may be passed against the Prime Minister by the National Assembly.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Extent of executive authority of Federation
texts.text: Extent of executive authority of Federation

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 97. Subject to the Constitution, the executive authority of the federation  shall  extend  to  the  matters  with  respect  to  which 1 [Majlis-eShoora (Parliament)] has power to make laws, including exercise of rights, authority and jurisdiction in and in relation to areas outside Pakistan :
texts.text: 97. Subject to the Constitution, the executive authority of the federation  shall  extend  to  the  matters  with  respect  to  which 1 [Majlis-eShoora (Parliament)] has power to make laws, including exercise of rights, authority and jurisdiction in and in relation to areas outside Pakistan :

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided  that  the  said  authority  shall  not,  save  as  expressly provided  in  the  Constitution  or  in  any  law  made  by 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)], extend in any Province to a matter with respect to which the Provincial Assembly has also power to make laws.
texts.text: Provided  that  the  said  authority  shall  not,  save  as  expressly provided  in  the  Constitution  or  in  any  law  made  by 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)], extend in any Province to a matter with respect to which the Provincial Assembly has also power to make laws.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Conferring of functions on subordinate authorities
texts.text: Conferring of functions on subordinate authorities

texts.orig: 98. On  the  recommendation  of  the  Federal  Government, 1 [Majlis-eShoora  (Parliament)]  may  by  law  confer  functions  upon  officers  or authorities subordinate to the Federal Government.

texts.text: Attorney-General for Pakistan

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 100. (1) The President shall appoint a person, being a person qualified  to  be  appointed  a  Judge  of  the  Supreme  Court,  to  be  the Attorney-General for Pakistan.
texts.text: 100. (1) The President shall appoint a person, being a person qualified  to  be  appointed  a  Judge  of  the  Supreme  Court,  to  be  the Attorney-General for Pakistan.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) The Attorney-General shall hold office during the pleasure of  the  President 2 [and shall  not  engage  in  private  practice  so  long  as  he holds the office of the Attorney-General].
texts.text: (2) The Attorney-General shall hold office during the pleasure of  the  President 2 [and shall  not  engage  in  private  practice  so  long  as  he holds the office of the Attorney-General].

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) It shall be the duty of the Attorney-General to give advice to the Federal Government upon such legal matters, and to perform such other duties of a legal character, as may be referred or assigned to him by the  Federal  Government,  and  in  the  performance  of  his  duties  he  shall have the right of audience in all courts and tribunals in Pakistan.
texts.text: (3) It shall be the duty of the Attorney-General to give advice to the Federal Government upon such legal matters, and to perform such other duties of a legal character, as may be referred or assigned to him by the  Federal  Government,  and  in  the  performance  of  his  duties  he  shall have the right of audience in all courts and tribunals in Pakistan.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (4) The  Attorney-General  may,  by  writing  under  his  hand addressed to the President, resign his office.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Conditions of Governor's office
texts.text: Conditions of Governor's office

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 103. (1) The  Governor  shall  not  hold  any  office  of  profit  in  the service  of  Pakistan  or  occupy  any  other  position  carrying  the  right  to remuneration for the rendering of services.
texts.text: 103. (1) The  Governor  shall  not  hold  any  office  of  profit  in  the service  of  Pakistan  or  occupy  any  other  position  carrying  the  right  to remuneration for the rendering of services.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) The  Governor  shall  not  be  a  candidate  for  election  as  a member of  1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] or a Provincial Assembly and, if a member of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] or a Provincial Assembly is appointed as Governor, his seat in 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] or, as the case may be, the Provincial Assembly shall become vacant on the day he enters upon his office.
texts.text: (2) The  Governor  shall  not  be  a  candidate  for  election  as  a member of  1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] or a Provincial Assembly and, if a member of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] or a Provincial Assembly is appointed as Governor, his seat in 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] or, as the case may be, the Provincial Assembly shall become vacant on the day he enters upon his office.

texts.text: (a) the  constituencies  for  the  general  seats  shall  be  single member  territorial  constituencies  and  the  members  to  fill such seats shall be elected by direct and free vote;

texts.text: (c) the  members  to  fill  seats  reserved  for  women  and  nonMuslims allocated to a Province under clause (1) shall be elected in accordance with law through proportional representation system of political parties' lists of candidates on the basis of the total number of general seats secured by each political party in the Provincial Assembly:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Duration of Provincial Assembly
texts.text: Duration of Provincial Assembly

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 107. A Provincial Assembly shall, unless sooner dissolved, continue for a  term  of  five  years  from  the  day  of  its  first  meeting  and  shall  stand dissolved at the expiration of its term.
texts.text: 107. A Provincial Assembly shall, unless sooner dissolved, continue for a  term  of  five  years  from  the  day  of  its  first  meeting  and  shall  stand dissolved at the expiration of its term.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Speaker and Deputy Speaker
texts.text: Speaker and Deputy Speaker

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 108. After  a  general  election,  a  Provincial  Assembly  shall,  at  its  first meeting and to the exclusion of any other business, elect from amongst its members a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker and, so often as the office of Speaker  or  Deputy  Speaker  becomes  vacant,  the  Assembly  shall  elect another member as Speaker or, as the case may be, Deputy Speaker.
texts.text: 108. After  a  general  election,  a  Provincial  Assembly  shall,  at  its  first meeting and to the exclusion of any other business, elect from amongst its members a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker and, so often as the office of Speaker  or  Deputy  Speaker  becomes  vacant,  the  Assembly  shall  elect another member as Speaker or, as the case may be, Deputy Speaker.

texts.text: 111. The Advocate-General shall have the right to speak and otherwise take part in the proceedings of the Provincial Assembly or any committee thereof of which he may be named a member, but shall not by virtue of this Article be entitled to vote.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1 [ 112. (1) The  Governor  shall  dissolve  the  Provincial  Assembly  if  so advised by the Chief Minister; and the Provincial Assembly shall, unless sooner  dissolved,  stand  dissolved  at  the  expiration  of  forty-eight  hours after the Chief Minister has so advised.
texts.text: 1 [ 112. (1) The  Governor  shall  dissolve  the  Provincial  Assembly  if  so advised by the Chief Minister; and the Provincial Assembly shall, unless sooner  dissolved,  stand  dissolved  at  the  expiration  of  forty-eight  hours after the Chief Minister has so advised.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation . -Reference  in  this  Article  to  'Chief  Minister'  shall not be construed to include reference to a Chief Minister against whom a notice  of  a  resolution  for  a  vote  of  no-confidence  has  been  given  in  the Provincial  Assembly  but  has  not  been  voted  upon  or  against  whom  a resolution for a vote of no-confidence has been passed.
texts.text: Explanation . -Reference  in  this  Article  to  'Chief  Minister'  shall not be construed to include reference to a Chief Minister against whom a notice  of  a  resolution  for  a  vote  of  no-confidence  has  been  given  in  the Provincial  Assembly  but  has  not  been  voted  upon  or  against  whom  a resolution for a vote of no-confidence has been passed.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2)    The  Governor  may  also  dissolve  the  Provincial  Assembly in  his  discretion,  but  subject  to  the  previous  approval  of  the  President, where  a  vote  of  no-confidence  having  been  passed  against  the  Chief Minister,  no  other  member  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  commands  the confidence of the majority of the members of the Provincial Assembly in accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the  Constitution,  as  ascertained  in  a session of the Provincial Assembly summoned for the purpose.]
texts.text: (2)    The  Governor  may  also  dissolve  the  Provincial  Assembly in  his  discretion,  but  subject  to  the  previous  approval  of  the  President, where  a  vote  of  no-confidence  having  been  passed  against  the  Chief Minister,  no  other  member  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  commands  the confidence of the majority of the members of the Provincial Assembly in accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the  Constitution,  as  ascertained  in  a session of the Provincial Assembly summoned for the purpose.]

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Restriction on discussion in Provincial Assembly
texts.text: Restriction on discussion in Provincial Assembly

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 114. No  discussion  shall  take  place  in  a  Provincial  Assembly  with respect  to  the  conduct  of  any  Judge  of  the  Supreme  Court  or  of  a  High Court in the discharge of his duties.
texts.text: 114. No  discussion  shall  take  place  in  a  Provincial  Assembly  with respect  to  the  conduct  of  any  Judge  of  the  Supreme  Court  or  of  a  High Court in the discharge of his duties.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Provincial Government's consent required for financial measures
texts.text: Provincial Government's consent required for financial measures

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 115. (1)    A Money Bill, or a Bill or amendment which if enacted and brought  into  operation  would  involve  expenditure  from  the  Provincial Consolidated Fund or withdrawal from the Public Account of the Province shall not be introduced or moved in the Provincial Assembly except by or with the consent of the Provincial Government.
texts.text: 115. (1)    A Money Bill, or a Bill or amendment which if enacted and brought  into  operation  would  involve  expenditure  from  the  Provincial Consolidated Fund or withdrawal from the Public Account of the Province shall not be introduced or moved in the Provincial Assembly except by or with the consent of the Provincial Government.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) For the purposes of this Article, a Bill or amendment shall be deemed to be a Money Bill if it contains provisions dealing with all or any of the following matters, namely:
texts.text: (2) For the purposes of this Article, a Bill or amendment shall be deemed to be a Money Bill if it contains provisions dealing with all or any of the following matters, namely:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax;
texts.text: (a) the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) the borrowing of money, or the giving of any guarantee, by the  Provincial  Government  or  the  amendment  of  the  law relating to the financial obligations of that Government;
texts.text: (b) the borrowing of money, or the giving of any guarantee, by the  Provincial  Government  or  the  amendment  of  the  law relating to the financial obligations of that Government;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (c) the custody  of the Provincial Consolidated  Fund,  the payment  of  moneys  into,  or  issue  of  moneys  from,  that fund;
texts.text: (c) the custody  of the Provincial Consolidated  Fund,  the payment  of  moneys  into,  or  issue  of  moneys  from,  that fund;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (d) the imposition of a charge upon the Provincial Consolidated  Fund,  or  the  abolition  or  alteration  of  any such charge;
texts.text: (d) the imposition of a charge upon the Provincial Consolidated  Fund,  or  the  abolition  or  alteration  of  any such charge;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (e) the receipt of moneys on account of the Public Account of the Province, the custody or issue of such moneys; and
texts.text: (e) the receipt of moneys on account of the Public Account of the Province, the custody or issue of such moneys; and

texts.orig: (3) A Bill shall not be deemed to be a Money Bill by reason only that it provides -
texts.text: (3) A Bill shall not be deemed to be a Money Bill by reason only that it provides -

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) for the imposition or alteration of any  fine or other pecuniary  penalty  or  for  the  demand  or  payment  of  a licence fee or a fee or charge for any service rendered; or
texts.text: (a) for the imposition or alteration of any  fine or other pecuniary  penalty  or  for  the  demand  or  payment  of  a licence fee or a fee or charge for any service rendered; or

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) for the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation  of  any  tax  by  any  local  authority  or  body  for local purposes.
texts.text: (b) for the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation  of  any  tax  by  any  local  authority  or  body  for local purposes.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (4) If any question arises whether a Bill is a Money Bill or not, the  decision  of  the  Speaker  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  thereon  shall  be final.
texts.text: (4) If any question arises whether a Bill is a Money Bill or not, the  decision  of  the  Speaker  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  thereon  shall  be final.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (5) Every  Money  Bill  presented  to  the  Governor  for  assent shall  bear  a  certificate  under  the  hand  of  the  Speaker  of  the  Provincial Assembly that it is a Money Bill and such certificate shall be conclusive for all purposes and shall not be called in question.
texts.text: (5) Every  Money  Bill  presented  to  the  Governor  for  assent shall  bear  a  certificate  under  the  hand  of  the  Speaker  of  the  Provincial Assembly that it is a Money Bill and such certificate shall be conclusive for all purposes and shall not be called in question.

texts.text: (b) in the case of a Bill other than a Money Bill, return the Bill to the Provincial Assembly with a message requesting that the Bill, or any specified provision thereof, be reconsidered and  that  any  amendment  specified  in  the  message  be considered.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Bill not to lapse on prorogation, etc.
texts.text: Bill not to lapse on prorogation, etc.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 117. (1)    A  Bill  pending  in  a  Provincial  Assembly  shall  not  lapse  by reason of the prorogation of the Assembly.
texts.text: 117. (1)    A  Bill  pending  in  a  Provincial  Assembly  shall  not  lapse  by reason of the prorogation of the Assembly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) A Bill pending in a Provincial Assembly shall lapse on the dissolution of the Assembly.
texts.text: (2) A Bill pending in a Provincial Assembly shall lapse on the dissolution of the Assembly.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Provincial Consolidated Fund and Public Account
texts.text: Provincial Consolidated Fund and Public Account

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 118. (1) All  revenues  received  by  the  Provincial  Government,  all loans  raised  by  that  Government,  and  all  moneys  received  by  it  in repayment of any loan, shall form part of a consolidated fund, to be known as the Provincial Consolidated Fund.
texts.text: 118. (1) All  revenues  received  by  the  Provincial  Government,  all loans  raised  by  that  Government,  and  all  moneys  received  by  it  in repayment of any loan, shall form part of a consolidated fund, to be known as the Provincial Consolidated Fund.

texts.label: list_item

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Custody,  etc.,  of  Provincial  Consolidated  Fund  and  Public
texts.text: Custody,  etc.,  of  Provincial  Consolidated  Fund  and  Public

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Account
texts.text: Account

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 119. The custody of the Provincial Consolidated Fund, the payment of moneys into that Fund, the withdrawal of moneys therefrom, the custody of other moneys received by or on behalf of the Provincial Government, their  payment  into,  and  withdrawal  from,  the  Public  Account  of  the Province,  and  all  matters  connected  with  or  ancillary  to  the  matters aforesaid, shall be regulated by Act of the Provincial Assembly or, until provision in that behalf is so made, by rules made by the Governor.
texts.text: 119. The custody of the Provincial Consolidated Fund, the payment of moneys into that Fund, the withdrawal of moneys therefrom, the custody of other moneys received by or on behalf of the Provincial Government, their  payment  into,  and  withdrawal  from,  the  Public  Account  of  the Province,  and  all  matters  connected  with  or  ancillary  to  the  matters aforesaid, shall be regulated by Act of the Provincial Assembly or, until provision in that behalf is so made, by rules made by the Governor.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Annual Budget Statement
texts.text: Annual Budget Statement

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 120. (1) The Provincial Government shall, in respect of every financial year, cause to be laid before the Provincial Assembly statement of the estimated receipts and expenditure of the Provincial Government for that year, in this Chapter referred to as the Annual Budget Statement.
texts.text: 120. (1) The Provincial Government shall, in respect of every financial year, cause to be laid before the Provincial Assembly statement of the estimated receipts and expenditure of the Provincial Government for that year, in this Chapter referred to as the Annual Budget Statement.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) The Annual Budget Statement shall show separately -
texts.text: (2) The Annual Budget Statement shall show separately -

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) the  sums  required  to  meet  expenditure  described  by  the constitution  as  expenditure  charged  upon  the  Provincial Consolidated Fund; and
texts.text: (a) the  sums  required  to  meet  expenditure  described  by  the constitution  as  expenditure  charged  upon  the  Provincial Consolidated Fund; and

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) the sums required to meet other expenditure proposed to be made from the Provincial Consolidated Fund;
texts.text: (b) the sums required to meet other expenditure proposed to be made from the Provincial Consolidated Fund;

texts.label: text
texts.orig: and  shall  distinguish  expenditure  on  revenue  account  from  other expenditure.
texts.text: and  shall  distinguish  expenditure  on  revenue  account  from  other expenditure.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Expenditure charged upon Provincial Consolidated Fund
texts.text: Expenditure charged upon Provincial Consolidated Fund

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 121. The following expenditure shall be expenditure charged upon the Provincial Consolidated Fund:-
texts.text: 121. The following expenditure shall be expenditure charged upon the Provincial Consolidated Fund:-

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) the remuneration payable to the Governor and other expenditure  relating  to  his  office,  and  the  remuneration payable to -
texts.text: (a) the remuneration payable to the Governor and other expenditure  relating  to  his  office,  and  the  remuneration payable to -

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (i) the Judges of the High Court; and
texts.text: (i) the Judges of the High Court; and

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (ii) the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Provincial Assembly;
texts.text: (ii) the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Provincial Assembly;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) the  administrative  expenses,  including  the  remuneration payable to officers and servants, of the High Court and the Secretariat of the Provincial Assembly;
texts.text: (b) the  administrative  expenses,  including  the  remuneration payable to officers and servants, of the High Court and the Secretariat of the Provincial Assembly;

texts.orig: CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (c) all  debt  charges  for  which  the  Provincial  Government  is liable, including interest, sinking fund charges, the repayment or amortisation of capital, and other expenditure in connection with the raising of loans, and the service and redemption  of  debt on  the security of the Provincial Consolidated Fund;
texts.text: (c) all  debt  charges  for  which  the  Provincial  Government  is liable, including interest, sinking fund charges, the repayment or amortisation of capital, and other expenditure in connection with the raising of loans, and the service and redemption  of  debt on  the security of the Provincial Consolidated Fund;

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: (d) any  sums  required  to  satisfy  any  judgement,  decree  or award against the Province by any court or tribunal; and

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Procedure relating to Annual Budget Statement
texts.text: Procedure relating to Annual Budget Statement

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 122. (1) So  much  of  the  Annual  Budget  Statement  as  relates  to expenditure  charged  upon  the  Provincial  Consolidated  Fund  may  be discussed  in,  but  shall  not  be  submitted  to  the  vote  of  the  Provincial Assembly.
texts.text: 122. (1) So  much  of  the  Annual  Budget  Statement  as  relates  to expenditure  charged  upon  the  Provincial  Consolidated  Fund  may  be discussed  in,  but  shall  not  be  submitted  to  the  vote  of  the  Provincial Assembly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) So much of the Annual Budget Statement as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted to the Provincial Assembly in the form of demands for grants, and that Assembly shall have power to assent to, or to refuse to assent to, any demand, or to assent to any demand subject to a reduction of the amount specified therein:
texts.text: (2) So much of the Annual Budget Statement as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted to the Provincial Assembly in the form of demands for grants, and that Assembly shall have power to assent to, or to refuse to assent to, any demand, or to assent to any demand subject to a reduction of the amount specified therein:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) No  demand  for  a  grant  shall  be  made  except  on  the recommendation of the Provincial Government.
texts.text: (3) No  demand  for  a  grant  shall  be  made  except  on  the recommendation of the Provincial Government.

texts.orig: 123. (1) The  Chief  Minister  shall  authenticate  by  his  signature  a schedule specifying -
texts.text: 123. (1) The  Chief  Minister  shall  authenticate  by  his  signature  a schedule specifying -

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) the  grants  made  or  deemed  to  have  been  made  by  the Provincial Assembly under Article 122, and
texts.text: (a) the  grants  made  or  deemed  to  have  been  made  by  the Provincial Assembly under Article 122, and

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) the several sums required to meet the expenditure charged upon the Provincial Consolidated Fund but not exceeding, in  the  case  of  any  sum,  the  sum  shown  in  the  statement previously laid before the Assembly.
texts.text: (b) the several sums required to meet the expenditure charged upon the Provincial Consolidated Fund but not exceeding, in  the  case  of  any  sum,  the  sum  shown  in  the  statement previously laid before the Assembly.

texts.text: (2) The  schedule  so  authenticated  shall  be  laid  before  the Provincial Assembly, but shall not be open to discussion or vote thereon.

texts.orig: (a) that the amount authorized to be expended for a particular service for the current financial year is insufficient, or that a  need  has  arisen  for  expenditure  upon  some  new  service not included in the Annual Budget Statement for that year; or
texts.text: (a) that the amount authorized to be expended for a particular service for the current financial year is insufficient, or that a  need  has  arisen  for  expenditure  upon  some  new  service not included in the Annual Budget Statement for that year; or

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: (b) that  any  money  has  been  spent  on  any  service  during  a financial  year  in  excess  of  the  amount  granted  for  that service for that year;

texts.orig: the  Provincial  Government  shall  have  power  to  authorize  expenditure from  the Provincial Consolidated  Fund,  whether  the  expenditure is charged by the Constitution upon that Fund or not, and shall cause to be laid  before  the  Provincial  Assembly  a  Supplementary  Budget  Statement or,  as  the  case  may  be,  an  Excess  Budget  Statement,  setting  out  the amount of that expenditure, and the provisions of Articles 120 to 123 shall apply to those statements as they apply to the Annual Budget Statement.
texts.text: the  Provincial  Government  shall  have  power  to  authorize  expenditure from  the Provincial Consolidated  Fund,  whether  the  expenditure is charged by the Constitution upon that Fund or not, and shall cause to be laid  before  the  Provincial  Assembly  a  Supplementary  Budget  Statement or,  as  the  case  may  be,  an  Excess  Budget  Statement,  setting  out  the amount of that expenditure, and the provisions of Articles 120 to 123 shall apply to those statements as they apply to the Annual Budget Statement.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Votes on account
texts.text: Votes on account

texts.orig: 125. texts.orig: 128. (1)    The  Governor  may,  except  when  the  Provincial  Assembly is in session, if satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary to  take  immediate  action,  make  and  promulgate  an  Ordinance  as  the circumstances may require.
texts.text: 128. (1)    The  Governor  may,  except  when  the  Provincial  Assembly is in session, if satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary to  take  immediate  action,  make  and  promulgate  an  Ordinance  as  the circumstances may require.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) An Ordinance promulgated under this Article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of the Provincial Assembly and shall be subject  to  like  restrictions  as  the  power  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  to make laws, but every such Ordinance -
texts.text: (2) An Ordinance promulgated under this Article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of the Provincial Assembly and shall be subject  to  like  restrictions  as  the  power  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  to make laws, but every such Ordinance -

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1 [ 130. (1) There  shall  be  a  Cabinet  of  Ministers,  with  the  Chief Minister at its head, to aid and advise the Governor in the exercise of his functions.
texts.text: 1 [ 130. (1) There  shall  be  a  Cabinet  of  Ministers,  with  the  Chief Minister at its head, to aid and advise the Governor in the exercise of his functions.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) The Provincial Assembly shall meet on the twenty-first day following  the  day  on  which  a  general  election  to  the  Assembly  is  held, unless sooner summoned by the Governor.
texts.text: (2) The Provincial Assembly shall meet on the twenty-first day following  the  day  on  which  a  general  election  to  the  Assembly  is  held, unless sooner summoned by the Governor.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) After the election of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, the  Provincial  Assembly  shall,  to  the  exclusion  of  any  other  business, proceed  to  elect  without  debate  one  of  its  members  to  be  the  Chief Minister.
texts.text: (3) After the election of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, the  Provincial  Assembly  shall,  to  the  exclusion  of  any  other  business, proceed  to  elect  without  debate  one  of  its  members  to  be  the  Chief Minister.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (4) The  Chief  Minister  shall  be  elected  by  the  votes  of  the majority of the total membership of the Provincial Assembly:
texts.text: (4) The  Chief  Minister  shall  be  elected  by  the  votes  of  the majority of the total membership of the Provincial Assembly:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided that, if no member secures such majority in the first poll, a  second  poll  shall  be  held  between  the  members  who  secures  the  two highest numbers of votes in the first poll and the member who secures a majority of votes of the members present and voting shall be declared to have been elected as Chief Minister:
texts.text: Provided that, if no member secures such majority in the first poll, a  second  poll  shall  be  held  between  the  members  who  secures  the  two highest numbers of votes in the first poll and the member who secures a majority of votes of the members present and voting shall be declared to have been elected as Chief Minister:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided  further  that,  if  the  number  of  votes  secured  by  two  or more members securing the highest number of votes is equal, further polls shall be held between them until one of them secures a majority of votes of the members present and voting.
texts.text: Provided  further  that,  if  the  number  of  votes  secured  by  two  or more members securing the highest number of votes is equal, further polls shall be held between them until one of them secures a majority of votes of the members present and voting.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (5) The member elected under clause (4) shall be called upon by  the  Governor  to  assume  the  office  of  Chief  Minister  and  he  shall, before  entering  upon  the  office,  make  before  the  Governor  oath  in  the form set out in the Third Schedule:
texts.text: (5) The member elected under clause (4) shall be called upon by  the  Governor  to  assume  the  office  of  Chief  Minister  and  he  shall, before  entering  upon  the  office,  make  before  the  Governor  oath  in  the form set out in the Third Schedule:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided that there shall be no restriction on the number of terms for the office of the Chief Minister.
texts.text: Provided that there shall be no restriction on the number of terms for the office of the Chief Minister.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (6) The Cabinet shall be collectively responsible to the Provincial Assembly and the total strength of the Cabinet shall not exceed fifteen members or eleven percent of the total membership of a Provincial Assembly, whichever is higher:
texts.text: (6) The Cabinet shall be collectively responsible to the Provincial Assembly and the total strength of the Cabinet shall not exceed fifteen members or eleven percent of the total membership of a Provincial Assembly, whichever is higher:

texts.orig: (7) The Chief Minister shall hold office during the pleasure of the  Governor, but the Governor shall not exercise his powers under this clause unless he is satisfied that the Chief Minister does not command the confidence of the majority of the members of the Provincial Assembly, in which  case  he  shall  summon  the  Provincial  Assembly  and  require  the Chief Minister to obtain a vote of confidence from the Assembly.
texts.text: (7) The Chief Minister shall hold office during the pleasure of the  Governor, but the Governor shall not exercise his powers under this clause unless he is satisfied that the Chief Minister does not command the confidence of the majority of the members of the Provincial Assembly, in which  case  he  shall  summon  the  Provincial  Assembly  and  require  the Chief Minister to obtain a vote of confidence from the Assembly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (9) A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not a member of the Provincial Assembly shall, at the expiration of that period, cease to be a Minister and shall not before the dissolution of that Assembly be again appointed a Minister unless he is elected a member of that Assembly.
texts.text: (9) A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not a member of the Provincial Assembly shall, at the expiration of that period, cease to be a Minister and shall not before the dissolution of that Assembly be again appointed a Minister unless he is elected a member of that Assembly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (10) Nothing  contained  in  this  Article  shall  be  construed  as disqualifying  the  Chief  Minister  or  any  other  Minister  for  continuing  in office  during  any  period  during  which  the  Provincial  Assembly  stands dissolved,  or  as  preventing  the  appointment  of  any  person  as  Chief Minister or other Minister during any such period.
texts.text: (10) Nothing  contained  in  this  Article  shall  be  construed  as disqualifying  the  Chief  Minister  or  any  other  Minister  for  continuing  in office  during  any  period  during  which  the  Provincial  Assembly  stands dissolved,  or  as  preventing  the  appointment  of  any  person  as  Chief Minister or other Minister during any such period.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Extent of executive authority of Province
texts.text: Extent of executive authority of Province

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 137. Subject to the Constitution, the executive authority of the Province shall extend to the matters with respect to which the Provincial Assembly has power to make laws :
texts.text: 137. Subject to the Constitution, the executive authority of the Province shall extend to the matters with respect to which the Provincial Assembly has power to make laws :

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided that, in any matter with respect to which both 2 [Majlis-eShoora  (Parliament)]  and  the  Provincial  Assembly  of  a  Province  have power  to  make  laws,  the  executive  authority  of  the  Province  shall  be subject to, and limited by, the executive authority expressly conferred by the Constitution or by law made by 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] upon the Federal Government or authorities thereof.
texts.text: Provided that, in any matter with respect to which both 2 [Majlis-eShoora  (Parliament)]  and  the  Provincial  Assembly  of  a  Province  have power  to  make  laws,  the  executive  authority  of  the  Province  shall  be subject to, and limited by, the executive authority expressly conferred by the Constitution or by law made by 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] upon the Federal Government or authorities thereof.

texts.text: Advocate General for a Province

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 140. (1) The  Governor  of  each  Province  shall  appoint  a  person, being a person qualified to be appointed a Judge of the High Court, to be the Advocate General for the Province.
texts.text: 140. (1) The  Governor  of  each  Province  shall  appoint  a  person, being a person qualified to be appointed a Judge of the High Court, to be the Advocate General for the Province.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) It shall be the duty of the Advocate-General to give advice to  the  Provincial  Government  upon  such  legal  matters,  and  to  perform such other duties of a legal character, as may be referred or assigned to him by the Provincial Government.
texts.text: (2) It shall be the duty of the Advocate-General to give advice to  the  Provincial  Government  upon  such  legal  matters,  and  to  perform such other duties of a legal character, as may be referred or assigned to him by the Provincial Government.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) The Advocate-General shall hold office during the pleasure of the Governor 5 [and shall not engage in private practice so long as he holds the office of the Advocate-General].
texts.text: (3) The Advocate-General shall hold office during the pleasure of the Governor 5 [and shall not engage in private practice so long as he holds the office of the Advocate-General].

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (4) The  Advocate-General  may,  by  writing  under  his  hand addressed to the Governor, resign his office.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Extent of Federal and Provincial laws
texts.text: Extent of Federal and Provincial laws

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 141. Subject  to  the  Constitution, 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may make laws (including laws having extra-territorial operation) for the whole or any part of Pakistan, and a Provincial Assembly may make laws for the Province or any part thereof.
texts.text: 141. Subject  to  the  Constitution, 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may make laws (including laws having extra-territorial operation) for the whole or any part of Pakistan, and a Provincial Assembly may make laws for the Province or any part thereof.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Power of Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament) to legislate for  1 [One] or more Provinces by consent
texts.text: Power of Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament) to legislate for  1 [One] or more Provinces by consent

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 144. (1) If 1 [one]  or  more  Provincial  Assemblies  pass  resolutions to  the  effect  that 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may  by  law  regulate any  matter  not  enumerated  in 3 [the  Federal  Legislation  List]  in  the Fourth  Schedule,  it  shall  be  lawful  for 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)] to  pass  an  Act  for  regulating  that  matter  accordingly,  but  any  act  so passed  may,  as  respects  any  Province  to  which  it  applies,  be  amended or  repealed  by  Act  of  the  Assembly  of  that  Province.
texts.text: 144. (1) If 1 [one]  or  more  Provincial  Assemblies  pass  resolutions to  the  effect  that 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may  by  law  regulate any  matter  not  enumerated  in 3 [the  Federal  Legislation  List]  in  the Fourth  Schedule,  it  shall  be  lawful  for 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)] to  pass  an  Act  for  regulating  that  matter  accordingly,  but  any  act  so passed  may,  as  respects  any  Province  to  which  it  applies,  be  amended or  repealed  by  Act  of  the  Assembly  of  that  Province.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Power  of  President  to  direct  Governor  to  discharge  certain functions as his Agent
texts.text: Power  of  President  to  direct  Governor  to  discharge  certain functions as his Agent

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 145. (1)    The  President  may  direct  the  Governor  of  any  Province  to discharge as his Agent, either generally or in any particular matter, such functions relating to such areas in the Federation which are not included in any Province as may be specified in the direction.
texts.text: 145. (1)    The  President  may  direct  the  Governor  of  any  Province  to discharge as his Agent, either generally or in any particular matter, such functions relating to such areas in the Federation which are not included in any Province as may be specified in the direction.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) The  provisions  of  Article  105  shall  not  apply  to  the discharge by the Governor of his functions under clause (1).
texts.text: (2) The  provisions  of  Article  105  shall  not  apply  to  the discharge by the Governor of his functions under clause (1).

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Power of Federation  to  confer  powers,  etc.,  on  Provinces,  in certain cases
texts.text: Power of Federation  to  confer  powers,  etc.,  on  Provinces,  in certain cases

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 146. (1)    Notwithstanding  anything  contained  in  the  Constitution,  the Federal  Government  may,  with  the  consent  of  the  Government  of  a Province, entrust either conditionally or unconditionally to that Government, or to its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive authority of the Federation extends.
texts.text: 146. (1)    Notwithstanding  anything  contained  in  the  Constitution,  the Federal  Government  may,  with  the  consent  of  the  Government  of  a Province, entrust either conditionally or unconditionally to that Government, or to its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive authority of the Federation extends.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) An  Act  of 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may,  notwithstanding  that  it  relates  to  a  matter  with  respect  to  which  a  Provincial Assembly has no power to make laws, confer powers and impose duties upon a Province or officers and authorities thereof.
texts.text: (2) An  Act  of 2 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may,  notwithstanding  that  it  relates  to  a  matter  with  respect  to  which  a  Provincial Assembly has no power to make laws, confer powers and impose duties upon a Province or officers and authorities thereof.

texts.text: (3) Where  by  virtue  of  this  Article  powers  and  duties  have been  conferred  or  imposed  upon  a  Province  or  officers  or  authorities thereof, there shall be paid by the Federation to the Province such sum as may be agreed or, in default of agreement, as may be determined by an arbitrator  appointed  by  the  Chief  Justice  of  Pakistan,  in  respect  of  any extra costs of administration incurred by the Province in connection with the exercise of those powers or the discharge of those duties.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Power of the Provinces to entrust functions to the Federation
texts.text: Power of the Provinces to entrust functions to the Federation

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 147. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Constitution, the Government  of a Province may, with the consent of the Federal Government,  entrust, either conditionally or unconditionally, to the Federal Government, or to its officers, functions in relation to any matter to which the executive authority of the Province extends 1 [:]
texts.text: 147. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Constitution, the Government  of a Province may, with the consent of the Federal Government,  entrust, either conditionally or unconditionally, to the Federal Government, or to its officers, functions in relation to any matter to which the executive authority of the Province extends 1 [:]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2 [Provided that the Provincial Government shall get the functions so entrusted ratified by the Provincial Assembly within sixty days.]
texts.text: 2 [Provided that the Provincial Government shall get the functions so entrusted ratified by the Provincial Assembly within sixty days.]

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Obligation of Provinces and Federation
texts.text: Obligation of Provinces and Federation

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 148. (1) The  executive authority of every Province shall be so exercised as to secure compliance with Federal laws which apply in that Province.
texts.text: 148. (1) The  executive authority of every Province shall be so exercised as to secure compliance with Federal laws which apply in that Province.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) Without prejudice to any other provision of this Chapter, in the exercise of the executive authority of the Federation in any Province regard shall be had to the interests of that Province.
texts.text: (2) Without prejudice to any other provision of this Chapter, in the exercise of the executive authority of the Federation in any Province regard shall be had to the interests of that Province.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) It  shall  be  the  duty  of  the  Federation  to  protect  every Province  against  external  aggression  and  internal  disturbances  and  to ensure that the Government of every Province is carried on in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution.
texts.text: (3) It  shall  be  the  duty  of  the  Federation  to  protect  every Province  against  external  aggression  and  internal  disturbances  and  to ensure that the Government of every Province is carried on in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Directions to Provinces in certain cases
texts.text: Directions to Provinces in certain cases

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 149. (1) The  executive authority of every Province shall be so exercised  as  not  to  impede  or  prejudice  the  exercise  of  the  executive authority of the Federation, and the executive authority of the Federation shall extend to the giving of such directions to a Province as may appear to the Federal Government to be necessary for that purpose.
texts.text: 149. (1) The  executive authority of every Province shall be so exercised  as  not  to  impede  or  prejudice  the  exercise  of  the  executive authority of the Federation, and the executive authority of the Federation shall extend to the giving of such directions to a Province as may appear to the Federal Government to be necessary for that purpose.

texts.text: (3) The executive authority of the Federation shall also extend to  the  giving  of  directions  to  a  Province  as  to  the  construction  and maintenance of means of communication declared in the direction to be of national or strategic importance.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Full faith and credit for public acts, etc.
texts.text: Full faith and credit for public acts, etc.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 150. Full faith and credit shall be given throughout Pakistan to public acts and records, and judicial proceedings of every Province.
texts.text: 150. Full faith and credit shall be given throughout Pakistan to public acts and records, and judicial proceedings of every Province.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Inter-Provincial trade
texts.text: Inter-Provincial trade

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 151. (1) Subject  to  clause  (2),  trade,  commerce  and  intercourse throughout Pakistan shall be free.
texts.text: 151. (1) Subject  to  clause  (2),  trade,  commerce  and  intercourse throughout Pakistan shall be free.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may  by  law  impose  such restrictions  on  the  freedom  of  trade,  commerce  or  inter-course  between one  Province  and  another  or  within  any  part  of  Pakistan  as  may  be required in the public interest.
texts.text: (2) 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  may  by  law  impose  such restrictions  on  the  freedom  of  trade,  commerce  or  inter-course  between one  Province  and  another  or  within  any  part  of  Pakistan  as  may  be required in the public interest.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) A Provincial  Assembly  or  a  Provincial  Government  shall not have power to -
texts.text: (3) A Provincial  Assembly  or  a  Provincial  Government  shall not have power to -

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) make any law, or take any executive action, prohibiting or restricting  the  entry  into,  or  the  export  from,  the  Province of goods of any class or description, or
texts.text: (a) make any law, or take any executive action, prohibiting or restricting  the  entry  into,  or  the  export  from,  the  Province of goods of any class or description, or

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) impose  a  tax  which,  as  between  goods  manufactured  or produced in the Province and similar goods not so manufactured  or  produced,  discriminates  in  favour  of  the former goods or which, in the case of goods manufactured or  produced  outside  the  Province  discriminates  between goods  manufactured  or  produced  in  any  area  in  Pakistan and similar goods manufactured or produced in any other area in Pakistan.
texts.text: (b) impose  a  tax  which,  as  between  goods  manufactured  or produced in the Province and similar goods not so manufactured  or  produced,  discriminates  in  favour  of  the former goods or which, in the case of goods manufactured or  produced  outside  the  Province  discriminates  between goods  manufactured  or  produced  in  any  area  in  Pakistan and similar goods manufactured or produced in any other area in Pakistan.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Acquisition of land for Federal purposes
texts.text: Acquisition of land for Federal purposes

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 152. The  Federation  may,  if  it  deems  necessary  to  acquire  any  land situate in a Province for any purpose connected with a matter with respect to which 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] has power to make laws, require the  Province  to  acquire  the  land  on  behalf,  and  at  the  expense,  of  the Federation  or,  if  the  land  belongs  to  the  Province,  to  transfer  it  to  the Federation on such terms as may be agreed or, in default of agreement, as may  be  determined  by  an  arbitrator  appointed  by  the  Chief  Justice  of Pakistan.
texts.text: 152. The  Federation  may,  if  it  deems  necessary  to  acquire  any  land situate in a Province for any purpose connected with a matter with respect to which 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] has power to make laws, require the  Province  to  acquire  the  land  on  behalf,  and  at  the  expense,  of  the Federation  or,  if  the  land  belongs  to  the  Province,  to  transfer  it  to  the Federation on such terms as may be agreed or, in default of agreement, as may  be  determined  by  an  arbitrator  appointed  by  the  Chief  Justice  of Pakistan.

texts.orig: CHAPTER 3. -SPECIAL PROVISIONS

texts.text: 3 [(6)] 4 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  in  joint  sitting  may  from time to time by resolution issue directions through the Federal Government  to  the  Council  generally  or  in  a  particular  matter  to  take action  as 4 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)] may deem just and proper and such directions shall be binding on the Council.

texts.text: 3 [(7)]  If  the  Federal  Government  or  a  Provincial  Government  is dissatisfied  with  a  decision  of  the  Council,  it  may  refer  the  matter  to 4 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  in  a  joint  sitting  whose  decision  in  this behalf shall be final.

texts.orig: (2) Upon  receiving  such  complaint,  the  Council  shall,  after having  considered  the  matter,  either  give  its  decision  or  request  the President  to  appoint  a  commission  consisting  of  such  persons  having special knowledge and experience in irrigation, engineering, administration, finance or law as he may think fit, hereinafter referred to as the Commission.
texts.text: (2) Upon  receiving  such  complaint,  the  Council  shall,  after having  considered  the  matter,  either  give  its  decision  or  request  the President  to  appoint  a  commission  consisting  of  such  persons  having special knowledge and experience in irrigation, engineering, administration, finance or law as he may think fit, hereinafter referred to as the Commission.

texts.orig: (3) Until 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  makes  provision  by law in this behalf, the provisions of the Pakistan Commissions of Inquiry Act, 1956, as in force immediately before the commencing day shall apply to  the  Council  or  the  Commission  as  if  the  Council  or  the  Commission were a Commission appointed under that Act to which all the provisions of section 5 thereof applied and upon which the power contemplated by section 10A thereof had been conferred.
texts.text: (3) Until 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  makes  provision  by law in this behalf, the provisions of the Pakistan Commissions of Inquiry Act, 1956, as in force immediately before the commencing day shall apply to  the  Council  or  the  Commission  as  if  the  Council  or  the  Commission were a Commission appointed under that Act to which all the provisions of section 5 thereof applied and upon which the power contemplated by section 10A thereof had been conferred.

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: (4) After  considering  the  report  and  supplementary  report,  if any,  of  the  Commission,  the  Council  shall  record  its  decision  on  all matters referred to the Commission.

texts.text: (5) Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, but subject to the provisions of clause (5) of Article 154, it shall be the duty of the Federal Government  and  the  Provincial  Government  concerned  in  the  matter  in issue to give effect to the decision of the Council faithfully according to its terms and tenor.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (6) No proceeding shall lie before any court at the instance of any party to a matter which is or has been in issue before the Council, or of any person whatsoever, in respect of a matter which is actually or has been or might or ought to have been a proper subject of complaint to the Council under this Article.
texts.text: (6) No proceeding shall lie before any court at the instance of any party to a matter which is or has been in issue before the Council, or of any person whatsoever, in respect of a matter which is actually or has been or might or ought to have been a proper subject of complaint to the Council under this Article.

texts.orig: (2) The  National  Economic  Council  shall  review  the  overall economic  condition  of  the  country  and  shall,  for  advising  the  Federal Government and the Provincial Governments, formulate plans in respect of financial, commercial, social and economic policies; and in formulating such plans, it  shall,  amongst  other  factors,  ensure  balanced  development and regional  equity and  shall  also  be  guided  by  the  Principles  of  Policy set-out in Chapter 2 of Part II.
texts.text: (2) The  National  Economic  Council  shall  review  the  overall economic  condition  of  the  country  and  shall,  for  advising  the  Federal Government and the Provincial Governments, formulate plans in respect of financial, commercial, social and economic policies; and in formulating such plans, it  shall,  amongst  other  factors,  ensure  balanced  development and regional  equity and  shall  also  be  guided  by  the  Principles  of  Policy set-out in Chapter 2 of Part II.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) The  meetings  of  the  Council  shall  be  summoned  by  the Chairman  or  on  a  requisition  made  by  one-half  of  the  members  of  the Council.
texts.text: (3) The  meetings  of  the  Council  shall  be  summoned  by  the Chairman  or  on  a  requisition  made  by  one-half  of  the  members  of  the Council.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (4) The  Council  shall  meet  at  least  twice  in  a  year  and  the quorum  for  a  meeting  of  the  Council  shall  be  one-half  of  its  total membership.
texts.text: (4) The  Council  shall  meet  at  least  twice  in  a  year  and  the quorum  for  a  meeting  of  the  Council  shall  be  one-half  of  its  total membership.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (5) The  Council  shall  be  responsible  to  the  Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament) and shall submit an Annual Report to each House of Majlise-Shoora (Parliament)].
texts.text: (5) The  Council  shall  be  responsible  to  the  Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament) and shall submit an Annual Report to each House of Majlise-Shoora (Parliament)].

texts.text: Priority of requirements of natural gas

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 158. The Province in which a well-head of natural gas is situated shall have precedence over other parts of Pakistan in meeting the requirements from that well-head, subject to the commitments and obligations as on the commencing day.
texts.text: 158. The Province in which a well-head of natural gas is situated shall have precedence over other parts of Pakistan in meeting the requirements from that well-head, subject to the commitments and obligations as on the commencing day.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 159. (1) The  Federal  Government  shall  not  unreasonably  refuse  to entrust to a Provincial  Government  such  functions  with  respect to broadcasting and telecasting as may be necessary to enable that Government -
texts.text: 159. (1) The  Federal  Government  shall  not  unreasonably  refuse  to entrust to a Provincial  Government  such  functions  with  respect to broadcasting and telecasting as may be necessary to enable that Government -

texts.text: Provided that nothing in this clause shall be construed as requiring the  Federal  Government  to  entrust  to  any  Provincial  Government  any control  over  the  use  of  transmitters  constructed  or  maintained  by  the Federal Government or by persons authorised by the Federal Government, or over the use of receiving apparatus by person so authorised.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: National Finance Commission
texts.text: National Finance Commission

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 160. (1)    Within  six  months of  the  commencing  day  and  thereafter  at intervals not exceeding  five  years, the  President shall 1 constitute a National Finance Commission consisting of the Minister of Finance of the Federal Government, the Ministers of Finance of the Provincial Governments,  and  such  other  persons  as  may  be  appointed  by  the President after consultation with the Governors of the Provinces.
texts.text: 160. (1)    Within  six  months of  the  commencing  day  and  thereafter  at intervals not exceeding  five  years, the  President shall 1 constitute a National Finance Commission consisting of the Minister of Finance of the Federal Government, the Ministers of Finance of the Provincial Governments,  and  such  other  persons  as  may  be  appointed  by  the President after consultation with the Governors of the Provinces.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) It shall be the duty of the National Finance Commission to make recommendations to the President as to -
texts.text: (2) It shall be the duty of the National Finance Commission to make recommendations to the President as to -

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) the  distribution  between  the  Federation  and  the  Provinces of the net proceeds of the taxes mentioned in clause (3);
texts.text: (a) the  distribution  between  the  Federation  and  the  Provinces of the net proceeds of the taxes mentioned in clause (3);

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) the making of grants-in-aid by the Federal Government to the Provincial Governments;
texts.text: (b) the making of grants-in-aid by the Federal Government to the Provincial Governments;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (c) the exercise by the Federal Government and the Provincial Governments  of  the  borrowing  powers  conferred  by  the Constitution; and
texts.text: (c) the exercise by the Federal Government and the Provincial Governments  of  the  borrowing  powers  conferred  by  the Constitution; and

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (d) any other matter relating to finance referred to the Commission by the President.
texts.text: (d) any other matter relating to finance referred to the Commission by the President.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 161. 1 [(1)    Notwithstanding the provisions of Article 78
texts.text: 161. 1 [(1)    Notwithstanding the provisions of Article 78

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (a) the  net  proceeds  of  the  Federal  duty  of  excise  on  natural gas levied at well-head  and  collected by  the Federal Government,  and  of  the  royalty  collected  by  the  Federal Government, shall not form part of the Federal Consolidated  Fund  and  shall  be  paid  to  the  Province  in which the well-head of natural gas is situated.
texts.text: (a) the  net  proceeds  of  the  Federal  duty  of  excise  on  natural gas levied at well-head  and  collected by  the Federal Government,  and  of  the  royalty  collected  by  the  Federal Government, shall not form part of the Federal Consolidated  Fund  and  shall  be  paid  to  the  Province  in which the well-head of natural gas is situated.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (b) the net proceeds of the Federal duty of excise on oil levied at  well-head  and  collected  by  the  Federal  Government, shall  not  form  part  of  the  Federal  Consolidated  Fund  and shall be paid to the Province in which the well-head of oil is situated.]
texts.text: (b) the net proceeds of the Federal duty of excise on oil levied at  well-head  and  collected  by  the  Federal  Government, shall  not  form  part  of  the  Federal  Consolidated  Fund  and shall be paid to the Province in which the well-head of oil is situated.]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) The  net  profits  earned  by  the  Federal  Government,  or  any undertaking established or administered by the Federal Government from the bulk generation of power at a hydro-electric station shall be paid to the Province in which the hydro-electric station is situated.
texts.text: (2) The  net  profits  earned  by  the  Federal  Government,  or  any undertaking established or administered by the Federal Government from the bulk generation of power at a hydro-electric station shall be paid to the Province in which the hydro-electric station is situated.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation . -For the purposes of this clause "net profits" shall be computed by deducting from the revenues accruing from the bulk supply of  power  from  the  bus-bars  of  a  hydro-electric  station  at  a  rate  to  be determined by the Council of Common Interests, the operating expenses of  the  station,  which  shall  include  any  sums  payable  as  taxes,  duties, interest or return on investment, and  depreciations and  element  of obsolescence, and over-heads, and provision for reserves.
texts.text: Explanation . -For the purposes of this clause "net profits" shall be computed by deducting from the revenues accruing from the bulk supply of  power  from  the  bus-bars  of  a  hydro-electric  station  at  a  rate  to  be determined by the Council of Common Interests, the operating expenses of  the  station,  which  shall  include  any  sums  payable  as  taxes,  duties, interest or return on investment, and  depreciations and  element  of obsolescence, and over-heads, and provision for reserves.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Prior sanction of President required to Bills affecting taxation in which Provinces are interested
texts.text: Prior sanction of President required to Bills affecting taxation in which Provinces are interested

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 162. No Bill or amendment which imposes or varies a tax or duty the whole or part of the net proceeds whereof is assigned to any Province, or which  varies  the  meaning  of  the  expression  "agricultural  income"  as defined  for  the  purposes  of  the  enactments  relating  to  income-tax,  or which  affects the principles  on  which  under  any  of  the  foregoing provisions of this Chapter moneys  are  or may  be  distributable to Provinces, shall be introduced or moved in the National Assembly except with the previous sanction of the President.
texts.text: 162. No Bill or amendment which imposes or varies a tax or duty the whole or part of the net proceeds whereof is assigned to any Province, or which  varies  the  meaning  of  the  expression  "agricultural  income"  as defined  for  the  purposes  of  the  enactments  relating  to  income-tax,  or which  affects the principles  on  which  under  any  of  the  foregoing provisions of this Chapter moneys  are  or may  be  distributable to Provinces, shall be introduced or moved in the National Assembly except with the previous sanction of the President.

A Provincial  Assembly may by Act impose taxes, not exceeding such limits as may from time to time be fixed by Act of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)],  on  persons  engaged  in  professions,  trades,  callings  or employments,  and  no  such  Act  of  the  Assembly  shall  be  regarded  as imposing a tax on income.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Exemption of certain public property from taxation
texts.text: Exemption of certain public property from taxation

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 165. (1)    The Federal Government shall not, in respect of its property or income, be liable to taxation under any Act of Provincial Assembly and, subject to clause (2), a Provincial Government shall not, in respect of its property or income, be liable to taxation under Act of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)]  or  under  Act  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  of  any  other Province.
texts.text: 165. (1)    The Federal Government shall not, in respect of its property or income, be liable to taxation under any Act of Provincial Assembly and, subject to clause (2), a Provincial Government shall not, in respect of its property or income, be liable to taxation under Act of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)]  or  under  Act  of  the  Provincial  Assembly  of  any  other Province.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) If  a  trade  or  business  of  any  kind  is  carried  on  by  or  on behalf  of  the  Government  of  a  Province  outside  that  Province,  that Government may, in respect of any property used in connection with that trade  or  business  or  any  income  arising  from  that  trade  or  business,  be taxed  under  Act  of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  or  under  Act  of  the Provincial  Assembly  of  the  Province  in  which  that  trade  or  business  is carried on.
texts.text: (2) If  a  trade  or  business  of  any  kind  is  carried  on  by  or  on behalf  of  the  Government  of  a  Province  outside  that  Province,  that Government may, in respect of any property used in connection with that trade  or  business  or  any  income  arising  from  that  trade  or  business,  be taxed  under  Act  of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  or  under  Act  of  the Provincial  Assembly  of  the  Province  in  which  that  trade  or  business  is carried on.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (3) Nothing in this Article shall prevent the imposition of fees for services rendered.
texts.text: (3) Nothing in this Article shall prevent the imposition of fees for services rendered.

texts.orig: 166. The  executive  authority  of  the  Federation  extends  to  borrowing upon the security of the Federal Consolidated Fund within such limits, if any,  as  may  from  time  to  time  be  fixed  by  Act  of 1 [Majlis-e-Shoora (Parliament)], and to the giving of guarantees within such limits, if any, as may be so fixed.

texts.orig: Power of Auditor-General to give directions as to accounts
texts.text: Power of Auditor-General to give directions as to accounts

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 170. 4 [(1)]  The  accounts  of  the  Federation  and  of  the  Provinces  shall be kept in such form and in accordance with such principles and methods as the Auditor-General may, with the approval of the President, prescribe.
texts.text: 170. 4 [(1)]  The  accounts  of  the  Federation  and  of  the  Provinces  shall be kept in such form and in accordance with such principles and methods as the Auditor-General may, with the approval of the President, prescribe.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4 [(2) The  audit of the accounts of the Federal and  of the Provincial  Governments  and  the  accounts  of  any  authority  or  body established  by,  or  under  the  control  of,  the  Federal  or  a  Provincial Government  shall  be conducted  by  the Auditor-General, who  shall determine the extent and nature of such audit.]
texts.text: 4 [(2) The  audit of the accounts of the Federal and  of the Provincial  Governments  and  the  accounts  of  any  authority  or  body established  by,  or  under  the  control  of,  the  Federal  or  a  Provincial Government  shall  be conducted  by  the Auditor-General, who  shall determine the extent and nature of such audit.]

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Reports of Auditor-General
texts.text: Reports of Auditor-General

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 171. The reports of the Auditor-General relating to the accounts of the Federation shall be submitted to the President, who shall cause them to be laid  before  the 5 [both  Houses  of  Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  and  the reports of the Auditor-General relating to the accounts of a Province shall be submitted to the Governor of the Province, who shall cause them to be laid before the Provincial Assembly.
texts.text: 171. The reports of the Auditor-General relating to the accounts of the Federation shall be submitted to the President, who shall cause them to be laid  before  the 5 [both  Houses  of  Majlis-e-Shoora  (Parliament)]  and  the reports of the Auditor-General relating to the accounts of a Province shall be submitted to the Governor of the Province, who shall cause them to be laid before the Provincial Assembly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 172. (1)    Any property which has no rightful owner shall, if located in a Province, vest in the Government of that Province, and in every other case, in the Federal Government.
texts.text: 172. (1)    Any property which has no rightful owner shall, if located in a Province, vest in the Government of that Province, and in every other case, in the Federal Government.

texts.orig: (2) All  lands,  minerals  and  other  things  of  value  within  the continental shelf or underlying the ocean 1 [beyond] the territorial waters of Pakistan shall vest in the Federal Government.
